subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new font released
msgSnippet: To my eyes there are three problems with Thoth, although I m sure there are many who would disagree with me. 1. Yo-yo looks too much like a capital P from T.O.
messageBody:
To my eyes there are three problems with Thoth, although I'm sure there are many who would disagree with me.

1. Yo-yo looks too much like a capital P from T.O.  The top should be more rounded.
2. Eat slopes too far to the right.
3. Ha-ha should have a bit more curve to it -- more of a hook than a right angle.  However, I know that in my handwriting I rather deviate from the QM in this regard.  My ha-ha looks almost exactly like a mirror image of pipe -- QM doesn't do this.

I note that Kick looks in Thoth-font much the way I write it.  However, I think that the riser in Kick in the QM curves a little to the left.  I like the way it looks in Thoth-font, but it may not please someone who is more of a purist.

Thanks,
Greg

----- Original Message ----
From: Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...>
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, October 31, 2007 6:48:59 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] new font released

I have released a new font, which you can find in the files section in
the fonts directory. The new font is called Thoth. It also has a
counterpart, ThothUni, the Unicode version.

The Unicode version is based on the popular Gentium font, so it contains
thousands of glyphs, and one can use just ThothUni to mix up Traditional
orthography and QS in the same document by using just one font.

I consider Thoth to still be in its testing stage, so I appreciate any
feedback. In the zip file you will find the two fonts and a number of
PDF documents that I created using this font. The font looks best with a
program that recognizes the kerning (special space between letters). I
found that only XeLaTeX and InDesign recognized kerning. For this
reason, I included the PDF produced with XeLaTeX so you can see what the
font looks like displayed properly.

Paul
